channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: The Supreme Court hands DOGE a victory in accessing Social Security information
item.description: The Supreme Court has handed DOGE at least a temporary victory. The team can keep accessing information collected by the Social Security Administration, including medical and mental health records.

item.title: What the Musk-Trump feud means for SpaceX
item.description: The relationship breakdown between Elon Musk and the Trump administration could have big implications for Musk's company SpaceX, which the U.S. relies on for space- and defense-related services.

item.title: Amid Trump cuts, this scientist lost a $53 million NIH grant. Then he got it back
item.description: The Trump administration terminated a $53 million NIH grant to study how impaired blood flow in the brain can lead to dementia. The lead scientist fought the decision, and got the money back.

item.title: Protestors say ICE's tactics have become heavy-handed. ICE defends its operations
item.description: As the Trump Administration ramps up ICE enforcement, some members of the public are showing up to oppose it, leading to confrontations. We ask experts about the tactics used by ICE and protesters.

item.title: Researchers chase storms to learn more about hail before it hits the ground
item.description: Hail storm damage is on the rise, so researchers want to learn more about hail before it hits the ground to possibly improve forecasts.

item.title: For the first time, MLB is investing in a women's professional softball league
item.description: Major League Baseball is branching out. It's investing in women's softball. It's an acknowledgement of the popularity of women's sports in the U.S. and could help jumpstart a sustainable league.

item.title: Marianne Faithfull's posthumous EP is a return to her folk and pop roots
item.description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly talks with Andrew Batt, executive producer of Marianne Faithfull's posthumous EP Burning Moonlight.

item.title: Trump administration works on rule to limit how long people can keep rental aid
item.description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development wants to limit the amount of time people can get federal rental subsidies and add work requirements, according to an internal document seen by NPR.

item.title: Who owns a acoustic piano these days? Across the country, less people are buying them
item.description: The acoustic piano was once a fixture in middle class homes. That's not the case anymore. With the popularity of electronic keyboards and music software, who is in the market for acoustic pianos?

item.title: How the mega-popular band Turnstile keeps its Baltimore roots
item.description: The hardcore rock band Turnstile is back with a new album, Never Enough. Izzi Bavis talks about how they've kept their Baltimore roots while becoming one of the biggest rock bands in America.
